diseases.name: Aflatoxicosis
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of Aflatoxin B1 in moldy feed. Ducks are more sensitive than chickens.
diseases.description: Poisoning caused by toxins produced by mold (Aspergillus flavus) in feed ingredients like corn.
diseases.controlPrevention: Moisture control in grain storage; Use of Toxin Binders in feed.
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed immediately; High quality protein; Toxin binders.

diseases.name: Ascariasis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Ascaridia galli. Fecal-oral transmission of eggs.
diseases.description: Infestation with large roundworms in the small intestine. Competes for nutrients and causes physical blockage.
diseases.controlPrevention: Routine deworming program; Litter management.
diseases.treatment: Anthelmintics (Levamisole, Albendazole, Piperazine, Ivermectin).

diseases.name: Ascites Syndrome
diseases.transmission: Metabolic strain in fast-growing broilers; High altitude; Poor ventilation (dust/ammonia).
diseases.description: Water Belly. Accumulation of fluid in the abdomen due to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Straw-colored fluid in abdomen, Enlarged right heart).
diseases.controlPrevention: Ventilation management; Lighting programs to slow growth; Mash feed.
diseases.treatment: No cure. Fluid aspiration gives temporary relief but not practical.

diseases.name: Avian Influenza
diseases.transmission: Caused by Orthomyxovirus (Type A). Spread via wild birds, infected feces, air, contaminated feed/water/vehicles.
diseases.description: A highly contagious viral disease affecting respiratory, digestive, and nervous systems. Can be Low Pathogenic (LPAI) or High Pathogenic (HPAI). HPAI causes sudden massive mortality and is zoonotic (can infect humans).
diseases.diagnosis: RT-PCR (H5/H7/H9 genes); HI Test; Rapid Antigen Test; Necropsy (Hemorrhages in proventriculus/fat).
diseases.controlPrevention: Strict Biosecurity; Vaccination (where legal); Exclusion of wild birds; Quarantine new stock.
diseases.treatment: None for viral infection. Supportive care for LPAI. HPAI usually requires culling of the flock.

vaccines.name: Vaksimune AI H9
vaccines.details:
- Inactivated vaccine against Avian Influenza, H9N2 strain.
- Inactivated vaccine (oil emulsion)

diseases.name: Botulism
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of Clostridium botulinum toxin from rotting carcasses, maggots, or stagnant water.
diseases.description: Also called Limberneck. Paralytic disease caused by neurotoxin.
diseases.controlPrevention: Remove dead birds daily; Clean water lines; Avoid wet litter.
diseases.treatment: Remove source of toxin; Selenium/Antibiotics (for secondary); Laxatives (Molasses).

diseases.name: Cannibalism
diseases.transmission: Stress; Overcrowding; High light intensity; Nutrient deficiency (Sodium/Amino acids).
diseases.description: Behavioral vice where birds peck at feathers, toes, or vents of other birds.
diseases.controlPrevention: Beak trimming; Red light; Space management; Salt in water.
diseases.treatment: Isolate injured birds; Apply tar/anti-peck spray; Correct environmental stress.

diseases.name: Chronic Respiratory Disease
diseases.transmission: Caused by Mycoplasma gallisepticum (MG). Vertical transmission (breeder to chick) and horizontal (airborne).
diseases.description: Chronic disease affecting the respiratory system. Often complicates with E. coli to form CRD-Complex (CCD).
diseases.diagnosis: Serum Plate Agglutination (SPA); ELISA; PCR; Culture.
diseases.controlPrevention: Sourcing MG-free chicks; Biosecurity; Vaccination (Live/Killed).
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (Macrolides like Tylosin, Tilmicosin, or Tetracyclines).

diseases.name: Coccidiosis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Eimeria spp. (e.g., E. tenella, E. acervulina). Ingestion of sporulated oocysts from wet litter.
diseases.description: Protozoal disease damaging the intestinal tract. One of the most economically important diseases in poultry.
diseases.diagnosis: Microscopic examination of mucosal scrapings (Oocysts identification).
diseases.controlPrevention: Use of Coccidiostats in feed (rotation); Dry litter management; Vaccination.
diseases.treatment: Sulfa drugs (Sulfadiazine, Toltrazuril) or Amprolium in drinking water.

diseases.name: Colibacillosis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Escherichia coli. Spread via fecal contamination (egg shell penetration) or inhalation of dust.
diseases.description: Infection caused by E. coli, often occurring as a secondary infection following respiratory viral diseases or environmental stress.
diseases.controlPrevention: Sanitation; Water chlorination; Hatchery hygiene; Minimizing stress/ammonia.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (based on sensitivity test); Acidifiers in water; Probiotics.

diseases.name: Curled Toe Paralysis
diseases.transmission: Deficiency of Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin).
diseases.description: Nerve degeneration causing specific paralysis of the toes in young chicks.
diseases.controlPrevention: Riboflavin supplementation in breeder and starter diets.
diseases.treatment: Immediate Vitamin B Complex supplementation.

diseases.name: Duck Plague
diseases.transmission: Caused by Herpesvirus. Spread via contact with infected birds or contaminated water bodies.
diseases.description: Also known as Duck Virus Enteritis (DVE). Acute contagious disease affecting adult ducks, geese, and swans.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Hemorrhagic bands in esophagus/intestine); PCR; Virus Isolation.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination with Live Attenuated vaccine; Preventing contact with wild waterfowl.
diseases.treatment: None. Depopulation is often recommended due to carrier state.

diseases.name: Duck Viral Hepatitis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Duck Hepatitis Virus (Picornavirus). Spread via fecal-oral route and direct contact.
diseases.description: Acute, highly fatal disease of young ducklings (1-28 days old). Causes rapid death with liver necrosis. Older ducks are resistant.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Enlarged liver with hemorrhagic spots); PCR; Virus Neutralization.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccinating breeder ducks to provide maternal immunity; Strict isolation of ducklings.
diseases.treatment: Serum therapy (Hyperimmune serum) injected into ducklings during early outbreak.

diseases.name: Egg Drop Syndrome
diseases.transmission: Caused by Duck Adenovirus A. Transmitted vertically (egg) and horizontally (feces/water).
diseases.description: Disease affecting laying hens causing a sudden drop in egg production and quality failure, often in otherwise healthy-looking birds.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (Inactivated) before laying period; Hygiene.
diseases.treatment: None. Spontaneous recovery usually occurs after 4-10 weeks.

vaccines.name:
Vaksimune 
ND IB Plus EDS
vaccines.details: Inactivated vaccine combination of Newcastle Disease virus LaSota strain, Infectious Bronchitis strain M-41 variants 771 and QX, Egg Drop Syndrome'76  in oil emulsion.

vaccines.name: Vaksimune ND IB EDS
vaccines.details:
- Inactivated vaccine against Newcastle Disease (LaSota strain), Egg Drop Syndrome‚Äô76, and Infectious Bronchitis (M-41 strain).
- Inactivated vaccine (oil emulsion)
- Packing size: 500 & 1000 Doses

diseases.name: Encephalomalacia
diseases.transmission: Deficiency of Vitamin E or Selenium. Often due to rancid fats in feed destroying Vit E.
diseases.description: Also called Crazy Chick Disease. Degeneration of brain tissue in young chicks.
diseases.controlPrevention: Add Antioxidants to feed; Ensure fresh fat source.
diseases.treatment: Vitamin E and Selenium supplementation in water.

diseases.name: Fowl Cholera
diseases.transmission: Caused by Pasteurella multocida. Spread by rodents, cats, and contaminated soil/water.
diseases.description: Contagious bacterial disease causing septicemia. Can be acute (sudden death) or chronic (localized swelling). Affects chickens and ducks.
diseases.diagnosis: Bacterial Culture (Bipolar rods on Gram stain); PCR.
diseases.controlPrevention: Rodent control; Biosecurity; Bacterin Vaccination.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (Sulfonamides, Amoxicillin, Tetracyclines) - but recurrence is common.

diseases.name: Fowl Pox
diseases.transmission: Caused by Avipoxvirus. Spread by mosquitoes/mites (vectors) or direct contact through broken skin.
diseases.description: Slow-spreading viral infection causing cutaneous (dry) or diphtheritic (wet) lesions. Wet pox involves the upper respiratory tract and is more severe.
diseases.controlPrevention: Wing-web Vaccination; Mosquito control.
diseases.treatment: None. Remove diptheritic membranes if blocking breathing; Iodine on skin lesions.

vaccines.name: Vaksimune Pox
vaccines.details: Live vaccine of Fowl Pox of Beaudette strain, propagated in embryonated Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) eggs, in liquid form.

diseases.name: Histomoniasis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Histomonas meleagridis. Transmitted via Heterakis (cecal worm) eggs or earthworms.
diseases.description: Also known as Blackhead. Protozoal disease affecting the ceca and liver. Turkeys are most susceptible, but chickens carry it.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Target lesions on liver, Caseous cores in ceca).
diseases.controlPrevention: Deworming (Control Heterakis worms); Keeping chickens and turkeys separate.
diseases.treatment: No approved treatment in many countries. Nitroimidazoles (if legal).

diseases.name: Infectious Bronchitis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Coronavirus. Spread via airborne route (wind) over long distances and direct contact.
diseases.description: Acute highly contagious respiratory disease. The virus also damages the kidneys (nephrosis) and the reproductive tract, leading to permanent production issues.
diseases.diagnosis: RT-PCR (S1 gene sequencing); ELISA (rising titer); Virus Isolation.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination using serotypes matching the field strain (Mass, 4/91, etc.); Biosecurity.
diseases.treatment: None. Antibiotics may be used only to prevent secondary bacterial infections (E. coli).

vaccines.details:

vaccines.details: Live vaccine of attenuated Newcastle Disease and Infectious Bronchitis

vaccines.name:
Vaksimune
NDL IB Plus
vaccines.details: Inactivated vaccines of Newcastle Disease Genotype VII strain N018 and Infectious Bronchitis M-41 strain variants 771 and Qx in oil emulsion

diseases.name: Infectious Bursal Disease
diseases.transmission: Caused by Birnavirus. Highly resistant in the environment. Spread via fecal-oral route.
diseases.description: Also known as Gumboro. An acute, highly contagious viral infection in young chickens that targets the Bursa of Fabricius, causing immunosuppression.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Swollen/hemorrhagic bursa); PCR; ELISA; Agar Gel Precipitation (AGP).
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination of breeders (Maternal Antibody); Vaccination of chicks (Intermediate/Hot strains); Disinfection.
diseases.treatment: None. Supportive therapy (electrolytes, kidney flush) and good management to increase comfort.

vaccines.name: Vaksimune IBD D
vaccines.details:
- Live freeze-dried vaccine against Infectious Bursal Disease, LZD228 strain
Live vaccine (freeze-dried)
- Packing size: 500, 1000 & 2000 Doses

vaccines.name: Vaksimune IBD M+
vaccines.details:
- Live vaccine against Infectious Bursal Disease, Multrop strain,
Live vaccine (freeze-dried)
- Packing size: 500, 1000 & 2000 Doses

vaccines.name: Vaksimune IBD MHV
vaccines.details:
- Live freeze-dried vaccine of Infectious Bursal Disease 
- Live vaccine (freeze-dried)
- Administration by in-ovo or subcutan injection

diseases.name: Infectious Coryza
diseases.transmission: Caused by Avibacterium paragallinarum. Spread via direct contact, airborne droplets, and water.
diseases.description: Acute respiratory disease of chickens characterized by severe facial swelling and foul-smelling nasal discharge.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (Bacterin); All-in-All-out management; Depopulation of carriers.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (Sulfonamides, Erythromycin, Fluoroquinolones).

vaccines.name: Vaksimune Coryza L
vaccines.details: Bacterial inactivated vaccines Avibacterium paragallinarum serovars A of 0083 strain, serotype B of SPROSS and local strain, serotype C of Modesto strain in AI(OH)3 adjuvant

vaccines.name: Vaksimune Coryza LE
vaccines.details:
- Inactivated vaccine against Avibacterium paragallinarum serotypes A, B, and C
- Inactivated vaccine (water-in-oil-in-water emulsion)
- Packing size: 500, 1000 & 2000 Doses

diseases.name: Infectious Laryngotracheitis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Herpesvirus (Gallid herpesvirus 1). Spread via carrier birds (latent), airborne droplets, and fomites.
diseases.description: Respiratory disease characterized by severe difficulty breathing and bloody mucus. The virus establishes latent infection in recovered birds.
diseases.diagnosis: Histopathology (Intranuclear inclusion bodies); PCR; Virus Isolation.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (Eye drop/Water/Pox-vectored); Biosecurity to prevent introduction from carriers.
diseases.treatment: None. Antibiotics for secondary infection. Ensure good ventilation.

vaccines.name: Vaksimune ILT
vaccines.details:
- Live vaccine against Infectious Laryngotracheitis, Hudson strain
- Live vaccine (freeze-dried)
- Packing size: 500, 1000 & 2000 Doses

diseases.name: Leucocytozoonosis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Leucocytozoon caulleryi. Transmitted by biting midges (Culicoides) or black flies.
diseases.description: Blood parasite disease resembling malaria. Causes severe anemia and hemorrhage.
diseases.controlPrevention: Control insect vectors (screens, insecticides); Sulfonamide preventive.
diseases.treatment: Sulfonamides (Sulfamonomethoxine) + Pyrimethamine.

diseases.name: Marek's Disease
diseases.transmission: Caused by Herpesvirus (MDV). Spread via inhalation of infected dander (dust) from feather follicles.
diseases.description: Lymphoproliferative disease causing tumors in nerves and organs. One of the most ubiquitous avian infections worldwide.
diseases.controlPrevention: Hatchery Vaccination (HVT/Rispens) on Day 1 or in-ovo; Strict hygiene for young chicks.
diseases.treatment: None. Infected birds remain carriers for life. Cull affected birds.

diseases.name: Necrotic Enteritis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Clostridium perfringens (Toxin A/C). Triggered by gut damage or diet changes.
diseases.description: Acute enterotoxemia causing necrosis of the intestinal lining. Often linked to Coccidiosis damage or high fishmeal diets.
diseases.diagnosis: Necropsy (Gas-filled intestine, necrotic membrane); Gram stain of mucosal scrape.
diseases.controlPrevention: Control Coccidiosis; Probiotics; Organic acids; Avoid drastic feed changes.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (Penicillin, Amoxicillin, Bacitracin) in water.

diseases.name: Newcastle Disease
diseases.transmission: Caused by Avian Paramyxovirus 1 (APMV-1). Spread via inhalation (air), ingestion of feces, and contaminated equipment/people.
diseases.description: A contagious viral disease affecting poultry of all ages. Categorized by pathotype: Velogenic (High mortality), Mesogenic (Moderate), and Lentogenic (Mild). Affects respiratory, nervous, and digestive systems.
diseases.diagnosis: HI Test (Hemagglutination Inhibition); RT-PCR; Virus Isolation in embryonated eggs.
diseases.controlPrevention: Routine Vaccination program (Live & Killed vaccines); Good Biosecurity.
diseases.treatment: None. Supportive care (vitamins/electrolytes) to reduce stress and secondary bacterial infections.

vaccines.details: Inactivated vaccine of Newcastle Disease LaSota strain in oil emulsion.

vaccines.details: Inactivated Vaccine of Newcastle Disease Genotype VII N018 strain in 0,1 dose in oil emulsion.

vaccines.details: Live vaccine of attenuated Newcastle Disease and Infectious Bronchitis

vaccines.name:
Vaksimune
NDL IB Plus
vaccines.details: Inactivated vaccines of Newcastle Disease Genotype VII strain N018 and Infectious Bronchitis M-41 strain variants 771 and Qx in oil emulsion

diseases.name: Perosis
diseases.transmission: Deficiency of Manganese or Choline; Biotin/Niacin/Folic Acid deficiency.
diseases.description: Slipped Tendon. Deformity of the leg bone causing the Achilles tendon to slip out of its groove.
diseases.controlPrevention: Ensure adequate Manganese and Choline in feed.
diseases.treatment: None. The deformity is irreversible.

diseases.name: Prolapse
diseases.transmission: Laying large/double-yolk eggs; Obesity; Early light stimulation; High intensity light.
diseases.description: Blowout. Protrusion of the oviduct through the vent.
diseases.controlPrevention: Weight management during rearing; Reduce light intensity.
diseases.treatment: Isolate bird; Clean and gently push tissue back; Apply anti-peck spray.

diseases.name: Pullorum Disease
diseases.transmission: Caused by Salmonella Pullorum. Vertical transmission (egg) is primary.
diseases.description: Also known as Bacillary White Diarrhea. Highly fatal systemic disease of young chicks/poults. Vertically transmitted.
diseases.diagnosis: Rapid Whole Blood Test (for breeders); Bacterial Culture.
diseases.controlPrevention: Eradication (Test and Cull positive breeders); Purchasing from certified clean flocks.
diseases.treatment: Treatment not recommended (creates carriers). Focus on eradication.

diseases.name: Rickets
diseases.transmission: Deficiency or imbalance of Calcium, Phosphorus, or Vitamin D3.
diseases.description: Metabolic bone disease in young, fast-growing birds leading to soft and deformed bones.
diseases.diagnosis: Feed analysis; Histopathology of bone; Clinical signs.
diseases.controlPrevention: Correct feed formulation; Ensure proper Ca:P ratio (2:1); Vitamin D3 supplement.
diseases.treatment: Supplementation with water-soluble Vitamin D3 and Calcium.

diseases.name: Riemerella anatipestifer
diseases.transmission: Caused by Riemerella anatipestifer. Spread via respiratory route or foot lesions.
diseases.description: Also called New Duck Disease. A septicemic disease primarily affecting young ducks (1-8 weeks).
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (Bacterin); Good litter management; Stress reduction.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (Penicillin, Cephalosporins, Enrofloxacin) - Early treatment is key.

diseases.name: Salmonellosis
diseases.transmission: Caused by Salmonella Enteritidis/Typhimurium. Spread via pests, feed, vertical transmission.
diseases.description: Paratyphoid infection caused by non-host specific Salmonella. Public health concern (Zoonotic).
diseases.controlPrevention: Rodent control; Feed hygiene; Acidifiers; Probiotics.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics may reduce shedding but rarely eliminate carrier state.

diseases.name: Salt Poisoning
diseases.transmission: Accidental mixing error in feed or lack of fresh water.
diseases.description: Intoxication due to excessive intake of Sodium Chloride (Salt) or water deprivation followed by overdrinking.
diseases.controlPrevention: Ensure consistent fresh water supply; Check feed mixing.
diseases.treatment: Restrict water initially (give small amounts frequently) to prevent brain swelling.

diseases.name: Visceral Gout
diseases.transmission: Dehydration; High Calcium diet in young birds (urolithiasis); Nephrotoxic IB virus.
diseases.description: Accumulation of uric acid crystals on internal organs due to kidney failure.
diseases.controlPrevention: Ensure water availability; Low protein diet during recovery.
diseases.treatment: Electrolytes; Urine acidifiers (Ammonium Chloride/Potassium Chloride).
